title: Recovering Stoichiometry via Multi-Modal Fused Electron Tomography
content: The integration of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) tomography with traditional electron tomography allows for nanoscale chemistry analysis in three dimensions [1,2]. Traditionally, EDX/EELS tomography requires high radiation doses (e.g., > 107 e/Å2) that often exceed the threshold of specimen stability, especially for core excitation spectroscopy. The recent advent of fused multi-modal electron microscopy introduces opportunities to minimize the high dosage requirements [3,4]. Moreover, combining fused multi-modal microscopy with electron tomography results in three-dimensional chemical analysis of materials with significantly lower electron doses—up to a hundredfold less [4]. Here we show fused multi-modal tomography also improves chemical accuracy and provides stoichiometry without prior knowledge of elemental inelastic cross-sections.
